questions.text: Except in which of the following is laryngeal crepitus not present?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Laryngeal Crepitus Presence

Reason

Post-cricoid malignancy

Present (unless advanced)

Tumors in this area usually do not fix the larynx early

Hypopharyngeal abscess

Present or reduced

May affect laryngeal movement but not always abolish crepitus

Parapharyngeal abscess

Present or reduced

Can restrict lateral movement but does not fix larynx completely

Prevertebral abscess

Absent

Fixes the larynx to the spine, preventing movement

questions.text: What nerve is most likely to be damaged when the cough reflex is impaired due to alcohol ingestion and other conditions, resulting in the prevention of foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet?
CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. What is the staging?
questions.explanation:
T1

Tumor is limited to the subglottis. (Option A ruled out)

T2

Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility. (Option C ruled out)

T3

Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation. (Option D ruled out)

T4a

Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus). (Option B)

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension.

N2

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension.

N2a

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2b

Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2c

Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension

Na

Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension

Mx

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No Distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: Which of the following is a life-threatening nerve injury?
In a patient with laryngeal cancer who has undergone a total laryngectomy, determine the mode of voice production depicted in the provided image.
A 2-year-old child presented with the following X-ray finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Acute laryngotracheobronchitis:

Aspect

Acute Epiglottitis

Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis)

Diagnosis
  • Visualisation: Red and swollen epiglottis (avoid indirect laryngoscopy to prevent airway obstruction).
  • Lateral Neck X-ray: "Thumb sign" indicating swollen epiglottis.
  • Differentiated based on clinical features (e.g., absence of drooling, voice quality).
  • The "steeple sign" on an X-ray AP view shows a narrowing of the upper airway, often seen in croup.

X-Ray Imaging

Hospitalisation

Required due to the high risk of airway obstruction.

Often necessary due to potential breathing difficulties.

Treatment
  • Antibiotics: Parenteral administration (e.g., ampicillin, third-generation cephalosporins).
  • Steroids: Hydrocortisone or dexamethasone to reduce oedema.
  • Hydration: IV fluids if needed.
  • Humidified Oxygen: Via mist tent or croupette.
  • Intubation or Tracheostomy: In cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Antibiotics: Ampicillin 50 mg/kg/day against the H. influenza virus.
  • Humidification: Helps clear crusts and thick secretions that block the tracheobronchial tree.
  • Steroids: to reduce oedema.
  • Racemic Epinephrine: Used as a bronchodilator.
  • Intubation or Tracheostomy: Considered if obstruction worsens or lasts beyond 72 hours.

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for a patient experiencing breathing difficulties and unsuccessful extubation after undergoing a total thyroidectomy?
questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

questions.text: Which of the following organisms does not cause croup?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Cause

Parainfluenza virus (Types 1, 2, 3) - most common, RSV, Influenza, Adenovirus

Age Group

6 months - 3 years (most common)

Symptoms

1. Barking cough

2. Inspiratory stridor

3. Hoarseness

4. Respiratory distress

Steeple Sign on X-ray

Subglottic narrowing on AP neck X-ray

Treatment

Mild: Supportive care, humidified air

Moderate-Severe: Dexamethasone + Nebulized Epinephrine

questions.text: A 65 year old male presented with history of dysphagia, halitosis and aspiration pneumonia. A barium swallow was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Definition

A false diverticulum formed due to herniation of pharyngeal mucosa through Killian’s dehiscence

Cause

Cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction leading to increased pressure and pouch formation

Symptoms

1. Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)

2. Regurgitation of undigested food

3. Halitosis (bad breath)

4. Aspiration pneumonia

Diagnosis

Barium swallow X-ray (shows a posterior pharyngeal pouch)

Treatment

Endoscopic diverticulotomy (Dohlman’s procedure) or open diverticulectomy in large cases

questions.text: What is the TNM staging for a patient with carcinoma in the pyriform fossa, presenting with a 5 cm lesion on laryngoscopy, non-mobile right vocal folds, no lymph node involvement, and no distant metastasis?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Tumor Size/Extent

Vocal Cord Mobility

Lymph Node Involvement

Metastasis

T1

Tumor confined to one subsite of hypopharynx

Normal

No nodes (N0)

No (M0)

T2

Tumor extends to more than one subsite or adjacent areas

Normal

N0

M0

T3

Tumor >4 cm or vocal cord fixation

Fixed

N0

M0

T4a

Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., thyroid/cricoid cartilage, hyoid, thyroid gland, esophagus)

Fixed

N0/N+

M0

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral fascia, encases carotid artery, or involves mediastinal structures

Fixed

N0/N+

M0

questions.text: A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice the inspiratory stridor in the child, and the laryngeal examination is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Cause

Congenital floppy laryngeal cartilage, especially affecting the epiglottis and arytenoids

Symptoms

Inspiratory stridor (worse when supine, feeding, or crying)

Onset

At birth or within the first few weeks of life, peaks at 4–8 months, resolves by 12–24 months

Diagnosis

Flexible laryngoscopy → shows omega-shaped epiglottis, redundant arytenoid mucosa

Treatment

Observation in mild cases, surgical intervention (supraglottoplasty) in severe cases

questions.text: Which of the statement is true regarding laryngomalacia?

options.label: C
options.text: Most common congenital abnormality in newborn

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical management is required in most children

questions.correct_answer: C. Most common congenital abnormality in newborn
questions.explanation:
Laryngomalacia or congenital laryngeal stridor

  • Most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.
  • During inspiration, an excessively flaccid supraglottic larynx gets sucked in and causes the symptoms.

Clinical features:
  • Presents at birth or immediately after
  • Stridor:
    • Increases on crying (increased negative intrathoracic pressure pulls the epiglottis inward, covering the laryngeal inlet)
    • Stridor present in supine position (as the epiglottis covers the laryngeal inlet)
    • Subsides in prone position (as the epiglottis falls away from the larynx)
  • Cyanosis seen sometimes
  • Normal cry
  • Usually disappears by 2 years of age

 

Investigations:

 
  • Direct laryngoscopy:
    • Elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself giving an “omega-shaped” appearance.
    • Floppy aryepiglottic folds
    • Prominent aretynoids
  • Flexible laryngoscopy is the most preferred

Management:

 
  • Conservative treatment in most cases
  • Tracheostomy: If severe respiratory obstruction
  • Supraglottoplasty: If severe laryngomalacia

questions.text: A 45-year-old teacher presents to the physician with complaints of hoarseness and voice fatigue. She reports that these symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past few months, especially towards the end of the school day. She denies any history of smoking or excessive alcohol consumption. Flexible laryngoscopy image is given below. what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule)

Cause

Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers. )

Laterality

Bilateral or symmetrical

Location

 

 

Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This

is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord.

Appearance

 

Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage

Symptoms

Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation.

Treatment

 

 
  • Initially, voice rest.
  • If it fails -
  • microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament
  • Speech therapy

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a barking cough and noisy breathing. An anteroposterior view of x ray of the neck shows a steeple sign. What type of stridor is most commonly associated with this presentation?
Which vitamin deficiency leads to Laryngismus stridulus?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Etiology
  • Hypocalcemia (rickets, hypoparathyroidism)
  • GERD
  • Viral infections
  • Allergies
  • Stress/emotions
  • Cold air, smoke
  • Rare: neurological issues

Symptoms
  • Sudden stridor
  • Breath-holding
  • Cough/choke
  • Cyanosis
  • Anxiety
  • Normal between attacks
  • No fever (unless infection)

Investigations
  • Serum calcium, phosphate, vitamin D
  • Chest X-ray
  • Laryngoscopy (if needed)
  • pH probe (for GERD)
  • Allergy tests

Treatment
  • Acute:
  • Calm child
  • Humidified air
  • Oxygen if needed
  • Upright position
  • Underlying cause:
  • Correct calcium/vitamin D
  • Treat GERD
  • Avoid allergens
  • Supportive care for infections
  • Psychological support

Prevention
  • Adequate nutrition (vitamin D, calcium)
  • Manage triggers
  • Parental education

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule)

Vocal Polyp

(Option A)

 

Cause

Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.)
  • Sudden Vocal abuse like shouting (Men in the age group of 30-50 years).
  • Heavy smoking

Laterality

Bilateral or symmetrical

Unilateral

Location

 

 

Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This

is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord.

Same as vocal nodules.

Appearance

 

Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage

Smooth and pedunculated.

Symptoms

Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation.
  • Hoarseness of voice and diplophonia (double voice due to different vibrating frequencies of two vocal cords)
  • Large polyps- dyspnea, stridor, choking.

Treatment

 

 
  • Initially, voice rest.
  • If it fails -
  • microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament
  • Speech therapy
  • Microscopic excision
  • Speech therapy

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngeal cancer stage T1bNOMO?

options.label: A
options.text: Both vocal cords involved and fixed

options.label: B
options.text: Both vocal cords involved, and no metastasis

options.label: C
options.text: One vocal cord involved and metastasis

options.label: D
options.text: One vocal cord involved, and mobile

questions.correct_answer: B. Both vocal cords involved, and no metastasis
questions.explanation:
T1

Tumor is limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility.

T2

Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsites of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g. mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall of pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx.

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion.

T4a

Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

T1

Tumor limited to vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissures) with normal mobility.

T1a

Tumor is limited to one vocal cord.

T1b

Tumor involves both vocal cords.

T2

Tumor extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, and/or with impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion.

T4a

Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

T1

Tumor is limited to the subglottis.

T2

Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility.

T3

Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation.

T4a

Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension.

N2

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension.

N2a

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2b

Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2c

Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension

Na

Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension

Mx

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No Distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

Clinical Features

Caused by HPV infection

Wart-like or grape-like projections

Hoarseness

Stridor

questions.text: What would be the diagnosis for a 2-year-old child who has been experiencing fever, a cough that sounds like barking, and stridor for the past 2 days?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Acute laryngo tracheo bronchitis: 

Diagnosis

Clinical assessment based on symptoms such as the characteristic cough, stridor, and respiratory distress. In severe cases, imaging studies like neck x-rays or laryngoscopy may be performed.

Clinical Features

1.

Barking Cough:

A distinctive cough that sounds like a seal or barking dog. 2.

Stridor:

High-pitched, inspiratory wheezing due to narrowed airways. 3.

Hoarseness:

Changes in the voice due to laryngeal involvement. 4.

Fever:

Often present, but usually low-grade. 5.

Respiratory Distress:

Rapid breathing, retractions (visible sinking of the chest or neck during inhalation), and difficulty breathing. 6.

Nasal Flaring:

In some cases, infants may exhibit nasal flaring.

questions.text: Life-saving muscle of vocal cords is:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Posterior

questions.text: Adam's apple seen in boys is because of:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Thyroid cartilag

Features

Description

Adam's Apple

The prominent thyroid prominence is more prominent in males due to hormonal and anatomical differences, giving rise to the characteristic visible bulge known as the Adam's apple.

questions.text: What are the initial signs of vocal fold growth?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B

questions.text: What are the structures that are not visible during indirect laryngoscopy?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A: Anterior Commissu

questions.text: Which muscle in the larynx is essential for saving lives as it retracts the vocal cords to enable breathing?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Larynx Muscle

Action

Cricothyroid muscle

Lengthens and tenses the vocal cords

Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle

Abducts (opens) the vocal cords

Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

Adducts (closes) the vocal cords

Transverse arytenoid muscle

Adducts (closes) the vocal cords

Thyroarytenoid muscle

Shortens and relaxes the vocal cords, contributing to vocalization

Vocalis muscle

Controls tension and fine adjustments of the vocal cords

Interarytenoid muscles (Oblique and Transverse)

Adducts (closes) the posterior part of the vocal cords
